text: GIANNESCHI: You break through this barrier of not having to look at static, dead systems and instead
look at live systems, and you’ve suddenly opened up a whole new window on these kinds of materials.
GIANNESCHI: You can imagine having a fairly shallow swimming pool filled with great white sharks that’s
completely covered, and you have a camera looking down just through a little hole in it.

They’re not really completely naturally
swimming, but you do get a better view than

if you just froze them in ice or cut them
in half and stuck them on a flat surface.
You can see them come close to each other, and then they collide, and they form this narrow
neck, and then they slowly sort of morph together, and they kind of go through an ellipsoidal structure
Sometimes they kind of come near each other and they kind of dance around a bit and then
you'll see them come apart again.
